commit_message:
Don't try to predetermine the Sahara URL

Because guess what, times have changed. When that code was written
version discovery wasn't what it is today...

Without this change, we couldn't handle unversioned endpoints in the
service catalog.

Closes-Bug: #1745083

Change-Id: Ie82e8a67b2820909625719c5f8a39ca0e1e2fbc0

commit_message:
Revise s3_hadoop

* Handle Hadoop classpath better
* Include proper support for Spark classpath
* Formally limit element's use to Vanilla and Spark

Change-Id: I65abd7e375dba11599a4ab943d24f878235cd71d
Closes-Bug: #1727757
Closes-Bug: #1728061

commit_message:
Fix pacemaker_running boolean

In legacy deployments this caused the resource agents to fail being
installed because the role was trying to install it on non-pacemaker
nodes.

Change-Id: Ic841ead2132abfff4ce4c6d739d1afd0cca11ee5
Closes-Bug: #1748196

[{'created': '2017-09-20 20:54:29.000000000', 'message': "Prioritise resource deletion over creation

Because of quotas, there are times when creating a resource and then
deleting another resource may fail where doing it in the reverse order
would work, even though the resources are independent of one another.

When enqueueing 'check_resource' messages, send those for cleanup nodes
prior to those for update nodes. This means that all things being equal
(i.e. no dependency relationship), deletions will be started first. It
doesn't guarantee success when quotas allow, since only a dependency
relationship will cause Heat to wait for the deletion to complete before
starting creation, but it is a risk-free way to give us a better chance of
succeeding.

Change-Id: I9727d906cd0ad8c4bf9c5e632a47af6d7aad0c72
Partial-Bug: #1713900
"}, {'created': '2017-09-26 20:54:54.000000000', 'message': "Prioritise resource deletion over creation

commit_message:
Prioritise resource deletion over creation

Because of quotas, there are times when creating a resource and then
deleting another resource may fail where doing it in the reverse order
would work, even though the resources are independent of one another.

When enqueueing 'check_resource' messages, send those for cleanup nodes
prior to those for update nodes. This means that all things being equal
(i.e. no dependency relationship), deletions will be started first. It
doesn't guarantee success when quotas allow, since only a dependency
relationship will cause Heat to wait for the deletion to complete before
starting creation, but it is a risk-free way to give us a better chance of
succeeding.

Change-Id: I9727d906cd0ad8c4bf9c5e632a47af6d7aad0c72

commit_message:
Align Vers Neg Middleware to current API

Fixes the version neg hiding API v2.6 if the deployment has
disabled the Image Import feature. Being current API 2.6 should
be always returned.

Change-Id: I69ac7f36f4fbb633c731be439b69c2a682b91238

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-29 19:23:36.000000000', 'message': 'Stop globally caching host states in scheduler HostManager

Currently, in the scheduler HostManager, we cache host states in
a map global to all requests. This used to be okay because we were
always querying the entire compute node list for every request to
pass on to filtering. So we cached the host states globally and
updated them per request and removed "dead nodes" from the cache
(compute nodes still in the cache that were not returned from
ComputeNodeList.get_all).

As of Ocata, we started filtering our ComputeNodeList query based on
an answer from placement about which resource providers could satisfy
the request, instead of querying the entire compute node list every
time. This is much more efficient (don't consider compute nodes that
can't possibly fulfill the request) BUT it doesn't play well with the
global host state cache. We started seeing "Removing dead compute node"
messages in the logs, signaling removal of compute nodes from the
global cache when compute nodes were actually available.

If request A comes in and all compute nodes can satisfy its request,
then request B arrives concurrently and no compute nodes can satisfy
its request, the request B request will remove all the compute nodes
from the global host state cache and then request A will get "no valid
hosts" at the filtering stage because get_host_states_by_uuids returns
a generator that hands out hosts from the global host state cache.

This removes the global host state cache from the scheduler HostManager
and instead generates a fresh host state map per request and uses that
to return hosts from the generator. Because we're filtering the
ComputeNodeList based on a placement query per request, each request
can have a completely different set of compute nodes that can fulfill
it, so we're not gaining much by caching host states anyway.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dansmith@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: #1742827
Related-Bug: #1739323

Change-Id: I40c17ed88f50ecbdedc4daf368fff10e90e7be11
(cherry picked from commit c98ac6adc561d70d34c724703a437b8435e6ddfa)
'}]
commit_message:
Stop globally caching host states in scheduler HostManager

Currently, in the scheduler HostManager, we cache host states in
a map global to all requests. This used to be okay because we were
always querying the entire compute node list for every request to
pass on to filtering. So we cached the host states globally and
updated them per request and removed "dead nodes" from the cache
(compute nodes still in the cache that were not returned from
ComputeNodeList.get_all).

As of Ocata, we started filtering our ComputeNodeList query based on
an answer from placement about which resource providers could satisfy
the request, instead of querying the entire compute node list every
time. This is much more efficient (don't consider compute nodes that
can't possibly fulfill the request) BUT it doesn't play well with the
global host state cache. We started seeing "Removing dead compute node"
messages in the logs, signaling removal of compute nodes from the
global cache when compute nodes were actually available.

If request A comes in and all compute nodes can satisfy its request,
then request B arrives concurrently and no compute nodes can satisfy
its request, the request B request will remove all the compute nodes
from the global host state cache and then request A will get "no valid
hosts" at the filtering stage because get_host_states_by_uuids returns
a generator that hands out hosts from the global host state cache.

This removes the global host state cache from the scheduler HostManager
and instead generates a fresh host state map per request and uses that
to return hosts from the generator. Because we're filtering the
ComputeNodeList based on a placement query per request, each request
can have a completely different set of compute nodes that can fulfill
it, so we're not gaining much by caching host states anyway.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dansmith@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: #1742827
Related-Bug: #1739323

Change-Id: I40c17ed88f50ecbdedc4daf368fff10e90e7be11
(cherry picked from commit c98ac6adc561d70d34c724703a437b8435e6ddfa)

commit_message:
Helm-Toolkit: move keystone service jobs to helm-toolkit

This PS moves the keystone service jobs to be driven by
a helm-toolkit function providing greater consistency
to the charts in OSH, and reduced tech debt.

Change-Id: I36e012854473fcb942d62391d182ee6a8406bb72

commit_message:
Unmap compute nodes when deleting host mapping

When we delete a host mapping in the api database, we need to mark
the compute node record as unmapped. Otherwise we can never re-discover
it if added back.

Change-Id: I9348827c5fd0364727e49cb8fae786cb2a29472a
Closes-Bug: #1735719
(cherry picked from commit 8ad36d15e404bf0dce90bed57f8aa91a350ed341)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-10 11:42:13.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: use 'host-passthrough' as default on AArch64

Nova is assuming 'host-model' for KVM/QEMU setup.

On AArch64 it results in "libvirtError: unsupported configuration: CPU
mode 'host-model' for aarch64 kvm domain on aarch64 host is not
supported by hypervisor" message.

AArch64 lacks 'host-model' support because neither libvirt nor QEMU
are able to tell what the host CPU model exactly is. And there is no
CPU description code for ARM(64) at this point.

So instead we fallback to 'host-passthrough' to get VM instances
running. This will completely break live migration, *unless* all the
Compute nodes (running libvirtd) have *identical* CPUs.

Small summary: https://marcin.juszkiewicz.com.pl/2018/01/04/today-i-was-fighting-with-nova-no-idea-who-won/

Closes-bug: #1741230

Co-authored-by: Kevin Zhao <Kevin.Zhao@arm.com>
Co-authored-by: Marcin Juszkiewicz <marcin.juszkiewicz@linaro.org>

Change-Id: Iafb5f1790d68489db73b9f0549333108c6426a00
(cherry-picked from commit 8bc7b950b7c0a3c80cdd120fe4df97c14848c344)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: use 'host-passthrough' as default on AArch64

Nova is assuming 'host-model' for KVM/QEMU setup.

On AArch64 it results in "libvirtError: unsupported configuration: CPU
mode 'host-model' for aarch64 kvm domain on aarch64 host is not
supported by hypervisor" message.

AArch64 lacks 'host-model' support because neither libvirt nor QEMU
are able to tell what the host CPU model exactly is. And there is no
CPU description code for ARM(64) at this point.

So instead we fallback to 'host-passthrough' to get VM instances
running. This will completely break live migration, *unless* all the
Compute nodes (running libvirtd) have *identical* CPUs.

Small summary: https://marcin.juszkiewicz.com.pl/2018/01/04/today-i-was-fighting-with-nova-no-idea-who-won/

Closes-bug: #1741230

Co-authored-by: Kevin Zhao <Kevin.Zhao@arm.com>
Co-authored-by: Marcin Juszkiewicz <marcin.juszkiewicz@linaro.org>

Change-Id: Iafb5f1790d68489db73b9f0549333108c6426a00
(cherry-picked from commit 8bc7b950b7c0a3c80cdd120fe4df97c14848c344)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-07 09:56:15.000000000', 'message': 'live-mig: keep disk device address same

During live migration disk devices are updated with the latest
block device mapping information for volumes.  Previously this
relied on libvirt to assign addresses in order after the already
assigned devices like the root disk had been accounted for.  In
the latest libvirt the unassigned devices are allocated first which
makes the root disk address double allocated causing the migration to
fail.  A running instance should never have the hardware addresses
of its disks changed mid flight.  While disk address changes during
live migration produce fatal errors for the operator it would likely
cause errors inside the instance and unexpected behavior if the device
addresses change during cold migrationt review.  With this disk addresses are no
longer updated with block device mapping information while every
other element of the disk definition for a volume is updated.

Closes-Bug: 1715569

Change-Id: I17af9848f4c0edcbcb101b30e45ca4afa93dcdbb
(cherry picked from commit b196857f04e41dde294eaacc2c1a991807ecc829)
'}]
commit_message:
live-mig: keep disk device address same

During live migration disk devices are updated with the latest
block device mapping information for volumes.  Previously this
relied on libvirt to assign addresses in order after the already
assigned devices like the root disk had been accounted for.  In
the latest libvirt the unassigned devices are allocated first which
makes the root disk address double allocated causing the migration to
fail.  A running instance should never have the hardware addresses
of its disks changed mid flight.  While disk address changes during
live migration produce fatal errors for the operator it would likely
cause errors inside the instance and unexpected behavior if the device
addresses change during cold migrationt review.  With this disk addresses are no
longer updated with block device mapping information while every
other element of the disk definition for a volume is updated.

Closes-Bug: 1715569

Change-Id: I17af9848f4c0edcbcb101b30e45ca4afa93dcdbb
(cherry picked from commit b196857f04e41dde294eaacc2c1a991807ecc829)

subject: Keep persistent systemd journals
messages:
[{'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-02-08 13:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7307, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So are these files rotated as part of standard log rotation?'}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:41:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Matt - journald has its own rotation schedule that it manages. Logrotate shouldn't touch those binary logs. The logs are compressed by default and kept under 10-15%. Docs here under "SystemMaxUse": https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/journald.conf.html'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-08 16:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-02-08 17:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

[{'created': '2018-02-08 13:52:14.000000000', 'message': 'Keep persistent systemd journals

This patch enables persistent systemd journals and allows a deployer
to disable the option if needed. The disk space requirements are
extremely low since the files are stored in binary format. It is
significantly less storage than rsyslog requires.

Closes-Bug: 1748195
Change-Id: I4de267f2839c5022e83a07fa7779f242808df5c0

commit_message:
Keep persistent systemd journals

This patch enables persistent systemd journals and allows a deployer
to disable the option if needed. The disk space requirements are
extremely low since the files are stored in binary format. It is
significantly less storage than rsyslog requires.

Closes-Bug: 1748195
Change-Id: I4de267f2839c5022e83a07fa7779f242808df5c0

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ic7caf6644d34bb53f9a9ec935d8a5c315d6fda80

[{'created': '2018-01-12 03:19:45.000000000', 'message': "Add support to build hadoop-2.8.2 related package

This patch include some modification to build hadoop 2.8.2
required packages.

   while building hadoop-openstack.jar. It is caused by change
   in hadoop upstream [1],[2]

commit_message:
Add support to build hadoop-2.8.2 related package

This patch include some modification to build hadoop 2.8.2
required packages.
1. Modify the hadoop-swiftfs/pom.xml to fix dependency error
   while building hadoop-openstack.jar. It is caused by change
   in hadoop upstream [1],[2]
2. Add hadoop version 2.8.2 into sahara-extra/tools/ to build
   related packages
3. make some changes on build-oozie.sh so that we don't need
   to replace hadoop.version in pom.xml. we can specify
   hadoop.version directly in the command.
4. Apply a workaround patch to oozie 4.3.0 to solve WebUI issue [3]
5. Insert a dependency into oozie/sharelib

[1]: https://github.com/apache/hadoop/commit/fa440a39b7883183b9cf43c056908ca7bf68e6a1
[2]: https://github.com/apache/hadoop/commit/12aa184479675d6c9bd36fd8451f605ee9505b47
[3]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/OOZIE-2533

Change-Id: I186cf5e01907cfab4a34507be464a0da170ebb5d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-24 21:53:30.000000000', 'message': "Use on-marked-down shutdown-sessions for redis haproxy conf

The problem we have with redis can be described as follows:
- Connection is made to redis via haproxy, where haproxy directs to one redis node
- That chosen redis node fails and a new redis node gets promoted
- HAProxy will send *new* connections to redis to the newly promoted
  redis server, but you still have a session active (ie. that has not hit
  timeout), so haproxy will attempt to use that connection.

By using 'on-marked-down shutdown-sessions' we make sure we close
old existing sessions when the redis master node changes.

NB: Cherry-pick not 100% clean due to some context differences

Closes-Bug: #1742086
Tested-By: Marian Krcmarik <mkrcmari@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ia4d8c27057ee2de9e49e4358aa069571d1c952a9
(cherry picked from commit dbfc8e1c1d5f39c7e64de7d7188cb2325492ee2a)

commit_message:
Use on-marked-down shutdown-sessions for redis haproxy conf

The problem we have with redis can be described as follows:
- Connection is made to redis via haproxy, where haproxy directs to one redis node
- That chosen redis node fails and a new redis node gets promoted
- HAProxy will send *new* connections to redis to the newly promoted
  redis server, but you still have a session active (ie. that has not hit
  timeout), so haproxy will attempt to use that connection.

By using 'on-marked-down shutdown-sessions' we make sure we close
old existing sessions when the redis master node changes.

NB: Cherry-pick not 100% clean due to some context differences

Closes-Bug: #1742086
Tested-By: Marian Krcmarik <mkrcmari@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ia4d8c27057ee2de9e49e4358aa069571d1c952a9
(cherry picked from commit dbfc8e1c1d5f39c7e64de7d7188cb2325492ee2a)
(cherry picked from commit 3eebb0b00b06dd8f57d8f17d5b822d7346b6d2f2)

[{'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-11 17:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-01-11 18:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-12105 : SUCCESS in 59m 32s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-01-11 21:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/532922/1/ : SUCCESS in 2h 19m 40s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-16 18:22:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We can now [1] do this via ProviderTree.snapshot(...).generation

But.

I'm not convinced we shouldn't still implement this accessor.  It's way lighter weight than creating a whole deep copy of the provider's attributes just to throw away everything but one int.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/533244"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-08 17:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is covered by ProviderTree.data (previously known as .snapshot).  Reasoning in previous comment still applies, but no strong motivation.  Can resurrect this later if necessary.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-11 17:39:08.000000000', 'message': "ProviderTree.generation_for

In preparation for driving changes from
ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree back to the placement service, we'll
need to be able to access the cached provider's generation.  This change
set introduces ProviderTree.generation_for, which accepts a provider
name or UUID and returns its generation (according to the cache).

Change-Id: Ia08e2be7e8a07ee61e9ffc05d24f82dd92c68838
"}]
commit_message:
ProviderTree.generation_for

In preparation for driving changes from
ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree back to the placement service, we'll
need to be able to access the cached provider's generation.  This change
set introduces ProviderTree.generation_for, which accepts a provider
name or UUID and returns its generation (according to the cache).

Change-Id: Ia08e2be7e8a07ee61e9ffc05d24f82dd92c68838

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ibf5e0bda88200cc18bbadd46bfd60ae435c2cbac

We're uploading all logs again, so this emergency measure is no
longer necessary.

commit_message:
Update MariaDB CentOS yum mirror URL

The yum mirrors for MariaDB have changes to the directory structure.
This patch updates the directory structure and chooses a faster
mirror from the US to use for installation.

Closes-Bug: 1747740
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/541698
Change-Id: I5f1ecb71c6125c29d6487bef6c2be215c1b561c1

commit_message:
Set rdo cloud mirrors in reproducer

Don't use rax mirrors when reproducing jobs, set mirrors for rdo
cloud instead. It should speed up the jobs.

Change-Id: I1c3e0e2b486414e48ba95f840b7947896414aae4

subject: Move sync_db parameter to glance::api
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 10873, 'name': 'Juan Antonio Osorio Robles', 'email': 'jaosorior@redhat.com', 'username': 'ejuaoso'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 19138, 'name': 'Pranali Deore', 'email': 'pdeore@redhat.com', 'username': 'PranaliD'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 19138, 'date': '2017-10-26 08:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19138, 'date': '2017-10-26 09:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19138, 'date': '2017-10-26 12:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2017-10-27 16:20:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I don't see it being backported to the branches between this and stable/newton (ex: pike, ocata).  Also, we're changing major functionality in a really old stable branch."}, {'account_id': 19138, 'date': '2017-10-30 05:05:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Mohammed Naser, there are issues in overcloud update in newton, glance services always gets restarted on update which ideally should not happen. This issue has been resolved in subsequent releases after applying patch [1] which is dependent on this change.

So, I guess this backport is must here.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/515333/'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2017-10-30 17:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

We can add the parameters, but we should not switch the db sync behavior. They should default to previous behavior and in tripleo, switch disable/enable them in the appropriate places (probably via THT)'}, {'account_id': 19138, 'date': '2017-11-10 05:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-02-08 16:42:22.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'm abandoning this as this does not follow our backport guidelines."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-26 08:14:57.000000000', 'message': "Move sync_db parameter to glance::api

Glance Registry will at some point be removed from puppet-glance once
API v1 is totally remove from Glance tree.
Some people using 100% v2 API don't need Glance Registry, so they don't
have to run glance::registry class. Though they need the db_sync, so
this patch aims to move the db_sync parameter from glance::registry to
glance::api.

The parameter in glance::registry is deprecated and will be removed in a
future release. Now people should use glance::api::sync_db.

Change-Id: Ib554edb13386845198140c87b0a9b931500656d2
(cherry picked from commit
465cd11025a9fb2df098dfbbd79051d5e168a472)
Conflicts:
	manifests/api.pp
	manifests/registry.pp
	spec/classes/glance_api_spec.rb
"}, {'created': '2017-10-26 09:06:48.000000000', 'message': "Move sync_db parameter to glance::api

commit_message:
Move sync_db parameter to glance::api

Glance Registry will at some point be removed from puppet-glance once
API v1 is totally remove from Glance tree.
Some people using 100% v2 API don't need Glance Registry, so they don't
have to run glance::registry class. Though they need the db_sync, so
this patch aims to move the db_sync parameter from glance::registry to
glance::api.

The parameter in glance::registry is deprecated and will be removed in a
future release. Now people should use glance::api::sync_db.

Change-Id: Ib554edb13386845198140c87b0a9b931500656d2
(cherry picked from commit
465cd11025a9fb2df098dfbbd79051d5e168a472)
Conflicts:
	manifests/api.pp
	manifests/registry.pp
	spec/classes/glance_api_spec.rb

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-02 00:26:51.000000000', 'message': "Replace use of functools.wraps() with six.wraps()

In Python 2.7, functools.wraps() does not provide the '__wrapped__'
attribute. This attribute is used by
oslo_utils.reflection.get_signature() when getting the signature of a
function. If a function is decorated without the '__wrapped__'
attribute then the signature will be of the decorator rather than the
underlying function.

From the six documentation for six.wraps():
    This is exactly the functools.wraps() decorator, but it sets the
    __wrapped__ attribute on what it decorates as functools.wraps()
    does on Python versions after 3.2.

Change-Id: Ic1c3e27e1578c914a86a2faf694c72dfdbfbda18
"}, {'created': '2018-02-08 09:17:45.000000000', 'message': "Replace use of functools.wraps() with six.wraps()

In Python 2.7, functools.wraps() does not provide the '__wrapped__'
attribute. This attribute is used by
oslo_utils.reflection.get_signature() when getting the signature of a
function. If a function is decorated without the '__wrapped__'
attribute then the signature will be of the decorator rather than the
underlying function.

From the six documentation for six.wraps():
    This is exactly the functools.wraps() decorator, but it sets the
    __wrapped__ attribute on what it decorates as functools.wraps()
    does on Python versions after 3.2.

Change-Id: Ic1c3e27e1578c914a86a2faf694c72dfdbfbda18
"}]
commit_message:
Replace use of functools.wraps() with six.wraps()

In Python 2.7, functools.wraps() does not provide the '__wrapped__'
attribute. This attribute is used by
oslo_utils.reflection.get_signature() when getting the signature of a
function. If a function is decorated without the '__wrapped__'
attribute then the signature will be of the decorator rather than the
underlying function.

From the six documentation for six.wraps():
    This is exactly the functools.wraps() decorator, but it sets the
    __wrapped__ attribute on what it decorates as functools.wraps()
    does on Python versions after 3.2.

Change-Id: Ic1c3e27e1578c914a86a2faf694c72dfdbfbda18

messages:
[{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-01-15 20:32:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-01-15 20:34:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-01-15 20:50:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-15 20:56:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-01-16 08:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I agree with Doug that it would be a better fit in the releases repository since repos under governance > repos under release management and we only want the latter to not be able to push tags by themselves.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-01-17 22:23:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Wouldn't putting it in the releases repo be kind of backwards? We want to watch out for official projects that are bypassing the expected release process."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-01-18 12:52:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@smcginnis: would you rather maintain a list of exceptions (with wildcards to catch e.g. openstack-infra/*) in the governance check tool ?

Also this would force fixing the ACL before even knowing that the repository is accepted, which can be a problem for example for new projects.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-01-21 15:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

If the goal is to analyze a cross-section between data in governance (official list of OpenStack deliverables) and project-config (Gerrit ACLs), then it becomes an integration test and would necessarily need to run against proposed changes to both repositories so as to avoid one deadlocking the other.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-01-23 09:35:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

I don't think the governance repo is the right place to store access control tools. That should be within the domain of the infra team or the release team. This repo is just a data store with a few scripts to gather stats and self-validate its own data. Other tools could of course check out this repository to get the list of official projects."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-31 18:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-02-08 16:33:00.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Replaced by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541931/'}]

commit_message:
Add gating to verify project access levels in Gerrit

Official projects must not be allowed to push tags.  This patch
adds a small tool to ensure that projects do not have this
permission to avoid any possible accidental tags.

Change-Id: I2bc13d3b549ba4e4ff6bc11833c1d74efb28afcb

openstack/releases to tag releases.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-07 02:20:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add PTP composable service

Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is a protocol used to
synchronize clocks throughout a network. When used
in conjunction with hardware support, PTP is capable
of sub-microsecond accuracy which is far better than
is normally obtainable with NTP.

Change-Id: I98a1833db28944cfd5a89e4f28c192bb9af8ebbb

commit_message:
Add PTP composable service

Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is a protocol used to
synchronize clocks throughout a network. When used
in conjunction with hardware support, PTP is capable
of sub-microsecond accuracy which is far better than
is normally obtainable with NTP.

Change-Id: I98a1833db28944cfd5a89e4f28c192bb9af8ebbb
Depends-On: Idc78df3a90b73be504480bc9d33a3f0041d2d84f

subject: Fix KEY_SHIFT keycode for libvirt
messages: [{'account_id': 11109, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:38:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11109, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:38:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2\n\nBugfix backport.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-08 15:38:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix KEY_SHIFT keycode for libvirt

In 2017, libvirt changed the way they handle keycodes (presumably when
they switched to the keycodemapdb repo). They dropped the KEY_SHIFT
keycode which used to be mapped to KEY_LEFTSHIFT, resulting in an
error "invalid keycode: 'KEY_SHIFT'" when building the basedisk with
KVM.

Fortunately, KEY_LEFTSHIFT existed before, so we can just use that and
it will work on both new and old versions of libvirt.

Change-Id: Iaddd068a6ee19d8c7f027558dcf3d3efea26dbbb
(cherry picked from commit 59ea77081067d6780daeb3449f3ee2181cf382f4)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix KEY_SHIFT keycode for libvirt

In 2017, libvirt changed the way they handle keycodes (presumably when
they switched to the keycodemapdb repo). They dropped the KEY_SHIFT
keycode which used to be mapped to KEY_LEFTSHIFT, resulting in an
error "invalid keycode: 'KEY_SHIFT'" when building the basedisk with
KVM.

Fortunately, KEY_LEFTSHIFT existed before, so we can just use that and
it will work on both new and old versions of libvirt.

Change-Id: Iaddd068a6ee19d8c7f027558dcf3d3efea26dbbb
(cherry picked from commit 59ea77081067d6780daeb3449f3ee2181cf382f4)

subject: Add Zhipeng Huang for Rocky Cyborg PTL election from the candidate
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 6088, 'name': 'Emmet Hikory', 'email': 'persia@shipstone.jp', 'username': 'persia'}, {'_account_id': 11878, 'name': 'Rushil Chugh', 'email': 'rushil.chugh@gmail.com', 'username': 'rushil'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 12898, 'name': 'Tony Breeds', 'email': 'tony@bakeyournoodle.com', 'username': 'tonyb'}, {'_account_id': 13629, 'name': 'Zhipeng', 'email': 'huangzhipeng@huawei.com', 'username': 'zhipengh'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 13629, 'date': '2018-02-08 03:49:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-02-08 03:53:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Let's see if this fixes the validation and display."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-02-08 04:22:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This wont work as expected.

You'll need to do either:
 1) Create 2 reviews 1; to remove candidates/rocky/Cyborg/zhipengh.txt and the second to create candidates/rocky/Cyborg/zhipeng.txt [1]; or
 2) Add a something like the following to exceptions.txt in this review:

  # Due to proxy nomination the associated candidate data is incorrect
  candidates/rocky/Cyborg/zhipeng.txt: Zhipeng Huang

However I'm not an election official and I strongly suggest we wait for feedback from them.

Longer term the election team has a change in mind to prevent this kind of issue from happening.


[1] I know that's basically what you'd done but git to smart enough to still attribute the content to rushil.chugh@gmail.com"}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-02-08 10:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The build-openstack-sphinx-docs job renders this unfortunately.  The scripts probably have to be adjusted to better handle non-self-nominations, as there is no strong requirement that the git author of a nomination is the nominee.   As this happens to be an uncontested election, we can ensure the formal email notifications are correct manually, even if we take a bit longer to sort the code so that it shows correctly.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-02-08 10:13:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do you think nothing is needed Emmet?

With speaking to Tony (my) last night, he pointed out the text of the election instructions did imply only self-nomination was allowed. He thought the best way to correct things was to have Zhipeng resubmit the nomination himself.'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-02-08 10:27:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

No, I think action is needed.  I just don't think this commit can solve the issue.  One way around it is to have two commits, one reverting the prior commit and one adding the correct file (but not as a rename).  Another is to adjust exceptions.txt (which I am considering along with other exceptions.txt processing we have for this cycle).  If you believe only self-nominations to be valid, that removes the third option, which I had previously preferred, of fixing the tooling to use different source information as input."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-02-08 10:32:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

I'm not sure if we've explicitly stated anywhere that it must be self-nomination. But after it was pointed out to me, the wording of the election instructions certainly seems to imply it.

I think either way we are OK. It was obviously Zhipeng's intention to nominate himself based on the post to the ML, so I don't think there should be any contention in declaring him the Rocky PTL. Just looking for the technical/procedural way to best clean up things at this point. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 13629, 'date': '2018-02-08 13:10:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

folks i'm kinda lost here, what is the concrete action item for me to follow up at this point ?"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-02-08 14:22:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You can propose a revert of 4eeb055b361973392f2ca1df24b8ae3ad7b2eefa and then propose that orriginal commit again yourself (if you want to push both at the same time, you'll want to stack them as a series of commits in Git so that the revert precedes the reproposal)."}, {'account_id': 13629, 'date': '2018-02-08 14:31:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> You can propose a revert of 4eeb055b361973392f2ca1df24b8ae3ad7b2eefa
 > and then propose that orriginal commit again yourself (if you want
 > to push both at the same time, you'll want to stack them as a
 > series of commits in Git so that the revert precedes the
 > reproposal).

shall I abandon this one then ?"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-02-08 14:36:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, you may as well abandon this. (You could reuse its Change-Id for the reproposal instead of abandoning, but it's probably just easier to abandon this and have a fresh proposal change following the revert.)"}, {'account_id': 13629, 'date': '2018-02-08 16:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

based upon suggestion'}]

commit_message:
If debug is enabled, provide verbose output for host discovery

In order to aid debugging, we add the '--verbose' CLI option to
the discovery command. This gives us a little more information
to work with when looking through the logs.

Change-Id: I194a1b20ceba4def8cac9591ef9bf0abf0b7f77f

commit_message:
Add shade jobs to openstacksdk zuul config

During rocky we'll be working on making shade a thin layer around sdk.
In order to make that work well, we need to make sure that sdk changes
don't break shade. shade also just added openstacksdk to the
requirements list for depends, so the jobs should currently make sure
requirements changes in sdk don't transitively break shade.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/541796
Change-Id: Ib4e7683c5ba312856a271a0473f4274569355f92

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I1ce8cc4423354e240a302367429d9a9726154896

commit_message:
Remove trailing slash in NODEPOOL_PUPPETLABS_MIRROR

Currently, variable NODEPOOL_PUPPETLABS_MIRROR for centos has an
extra slash character at the end. It seems this is not a problem when
using a mirror, but it fails when using puppetlabs yum repo as the
url [1] gives an 404 error, while [2] works fine.

[1] https://yum.puppetlabs.com//el/7/PC1/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml
[1] https://yum.puppetlabs.com/el/7/PC1/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml

Change-Id: Idf3a080322f117e62dec291f3047e9b5408813b9

commit_message:
Remove trailing slash in NODEPOOL_PUPPETLABS_MIRROR

Currently, variable NODEPOOL_PUPPETLABS_MIRROR for centos has an
extra slash character at the end. It seems this is not a problem when
using a mirror, but it fails when using puppetlabs yum repo as the
url [1] gives an 404 error, while [2] works fine.

[1] https://yum.puppetlabs.com//el/7/PC1/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml
[1] https://yum.puppetlabs.com/el/7/PC1/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml

Change-Id: Idf3a080322f117e62dec291f3047e9b5408813b9
(cherry picked from commit d209db89f2450222e87e8aa4b08cea59865e26e1)

commit_message:
Fix infinite loop issue

Running bandit using relative paths inside a subdirectory when the current
directory contains __init__.py causes bandit to be stuck in an infinite
loop.

Co-Authored-By: Calvin Li
Closes-Bug: #1743042
Change-Id: I247108c1365847134ee561073ea0eb43c57b54cc

commit_message:
Remove trailing slash in NODEPOOL_PUPPETLABS_MIRROR

Currently, variable NODEPOOL_PUPPETLABS_MIRROR for centos has an
extra slash character at the end. It seems this is not a problem when
using a mirror, but it fails when using puppetlabs yum repo as the
url [1] gives an 404 error, while [2] works fine.

[1] https://yum.puppetlabs.com//el/7/PC1/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml
[1] https://yum.puppetlabs.com/el/7/PC1/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml

Change-Id: Idf3a080322f117e62dec291f3047e9b5408813b9
(cherry picked from commit d209db89f2450222e87e8aa4b08cea59865e26e1)

subject: Fix KEY_SHIFT keycode for libvirt
messages: [{'account_id': 11109, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11109, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:37:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2\n\nBugfix backport.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-08 15:36:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix KEY_SHIFT keycode for libvirt

In 2017, libvirt changed the way they handle keycodes (presumably when
they switched to the keycodemapdb repo). They dropped the KEY_SHIFT
keycode which used to be mapped to KEY_LEFTSHIFT, resulting in an
error "invalid keycode: 'KEY_SHIFT'" when building the basedisk with
KVM.

Fortunately, KEY_LEFTSHIFT existed before, so we can just use that and
it will work on both new and old versions of libvirt.

Change-Id: Iaddd068a6ee19d8c7f027558dcf3d3efea26dbbb
(cherry picked from commit 59ea77081067d6780daeb3449f3ee2181cf382f4)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix KEY_SHIFT keycode for libvirt

In 2017, libvirt changed the way they handle keycodes (presumably when
they switched to the keycodemapdb repo). They dropped the KEY_SHIFT
keycode which used to be mapped to KEY_LEFTSHIFT, resulting in an
error "invalid keycode: 'KEY_SHIFT'" when building the basedisk with
KVM.

Fortunately, KEY_LEFTSHIFT existed before, so we can just use that and
it will work on both new and old versions of libvirt.

Change-Id: Iaddd068a6ee19d8c7f027558dcf3d3efea26dbbb
(cherry picked from commit 59ea77081067d6780daeb3449f3ee2181cf382f4)

commit_message:
Fix aodh service name check in tempest tests

The service name is aodh, not aodh_plugin, other projects like
tripleo are having these tests skipped because of this.

Change-Id: I650e39262e1972b0200bd11f45e231d1e5f9cf36
Depends-On: Ib77d29230aecd6148a02d1bd353b35d769291fdd

Zuul: Remove project name

Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

> Uploaded patch set 8.
It would be good to remove print and move the messages to sys.exit. Lets these messages go to stderr. stderr will be one place for people to look for messages and automate. Additionally, exit 1, 2 and 3 will not help because there are other sys.exit which may be called during_validate_engine and other APIs.
Other thing is, it might be good to change following style if conditions 
elif (not expand_heads or expand_heads not in curr_heads)
to 
elif ((not expand_heads) or (expand_heads not in curr_heads))
Just helps in readability.'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-02 09:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-02 09:48:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

 > Other thing is, it might be good to change following style if
 > conditions
 > elif (not expand_heads or expand_heads not in curr_heads)
 > to
 > elif ((not expand_heads) or (expand_heads not in curr_heads))
 > Just helps in readability.

Hi Prateek, Thanks for review.

--check feature implemented as per Lite Spec [1] 
Here expecting distinct return code while , and so implemted like wise.  

Yes, for readability will update style for conditions as suggested here and will upload latest patch. 

[1]: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/untargeted/glance/lite-spec-db-sync-check.html'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-05 06:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-05 10:37:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2018-02-05 11:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-05 12:52:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-05 16:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Just a few general comments.

This is a bit different from what's described in the spec, where the idea was more of a "dry-run" kind of thing as an option to db_sync.  I think it's useful to have this as a separate operation, however, because we don't know whether an operator is using db_sync or using the E-M-C commands separately.  So the output of this command provides useful information.

Also, although we only officially support MySQL for rolling upgrades, this db_check should be useful and accurate for people not doing rolling upgrades and/or using Postgres.

So, I'm not assigning a score ATM, I would like some input from other cores about whether the deviation from the lite-spec is acceptable (as I said earlier, I think it is).  I'll send out a quick email and ask people to comment on this review.  If the consensus is that this patch is OK, you'll need to put up a patch to revise the spec to reflect what was actually implemented.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2018-02-06 05:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> Just a few general comments.
 > 
 > This is a bit different from what's described in the spec, where
 > the idea was more of a "dry-run" kind of thing as an option to
 > db_sync.  I think it's useful to have this as a separate operation,
 > however, because we don't know whether an operator is using db_sync
 > or using the E-M-C commands separately.  So the output of this
 > command provides useful information.
 > 
 > Also, although we only officially support MySQL for rolling
 > upgrades, this db_check should be useful and accurate for people
 > not doing rolling upgrades and/or using Postgres.

Hi Brian, 

Just to inform you, we have just accepted a patch [1] which will use E-M-C internally for db_sync. So if someone wants to deploy glance with postgresql it will give error now (as we are adding a check in the said patch).

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433934/15  
 > 
 > So, I'm not assigning a score ATM, I would like some input from
 > other cores about whether the deviation from the lite-spec is
 > acceptable (as I said earlier, I think it is).  I'll send out a
 > quick email and ask people to comment on this review.  If the
 > consensus is that this patch is OK, you'll need to put up a patch
 > to revise the spec to reflect what was actually implemented.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2018-02-06 05:48:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> > Just a few general comments.
 > >
 > > This is a bit different from what's described in the spec, where
 > > the idea was more of a "dry-run" kind of thing as an option to
 > > db_sync.  I think it's useful to have this as a separate
 > operation,
 > > however, because we don't know whether an operator is using
 > db_sync
 > > or using the E-M-C commands separately.  So the output of this
 > > command provides useful information.
 > >
 > > Also, although we only officially support MySQL for rolling
 > > upgrades, this db_check should be useful and accurate for people
 > > not doing rolling upgrades and/or using Postgres.
 > 
 > Hi Brian,
 > 
 > Just to inform you, we have just accepted a patch [1] which will
 > use E-M-C internally for db_sync. So if someone wants to deploy
 > glance with postgresql it will give error now (as we are adding a
 > check in the said patch).
 > 
 > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433934/15

Just for curiosity I have tried to run above patch against postgresql (enabled postgresql in localrc file) by commenting _validate_engine method and found that devstack installation is completed without any issues which means E-M-C supports for postgresql as well. 

As above patch will get merged shortly user will not able to deploy glance with postgresql at all, in order to solve that we need to add postgresql engine name as well in the _validate_engine method.

 > >
 > > So, I'm not assigning a score ATM, I would like some input from
 > > other cores about whether the deviation from the lite-spec is
 > > acceptable (as I said earlier, I think it is).  I'll send out a
 > > quick email and ask people to comment on this review.  If the
 > > consensus is that this patch is OK, you'll need to put up a patch
 > > to revise the spec to reflect what was actually implemented.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2018-02-06 07:00:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> > > Just a few general comments.
 > > >
 > > > This is a bit different from what's described in the spec,
 > where
 > > > the idea was more of a "dry-run" kind of thing as an option to
 > > > db_sync.  I think it's useful to have this as a separate
 > > operation,
 > > > however, because we don't know whether an operator is using
 > > db_sync
 > > > or using the E-M-C commands separately.  So the output of this
 > > > command provides useful information.
 > > >
 > > > Also, although we only officially support MySQL for rolling
 > > > upgrades, this db_check should be useful and accurate for
 > people
 > > > not doing rolling upgrades and/or using Postgres.
 > >
 > > Hi Brian,
 > >
 > > Just to inform you, we have just accepted a patch [1] which will
 > > use E-M-C internally for db_sync. So if someone wants to deploy
 > > glance with postgresql it will give error now (as we are adding a
 > > check in the said patch).
 > >
 > > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433934/15
 > 
 > Just for curiosity I have tried to run above patch against
 > postgresql (enabled postgresql in localrc file) by commenting
 > _validate_engine method and found that devstack installation is
 > completed without any issues which means E-M-C supports for
 > postgresql as well.
 > 
 > As above patch will get merged shortly user will not able to deploy
 > glance with postgresql at all, in order to solve that we need to
 > add postgresql engine name as well in the _validate_engine method.
 > 
 > > >
 > > > So, I'm not assigning a score ATM, I would like some input from
 > > > other cores about whether the deviation from the lite-spec is
 > > > acceptable (as I said earlier, I think it is).  I'll send out a
 > > > quick email and ask people to comment on this review.  If the
 > > > consensus is that this patch is OK, you'll need to put up a
 > patch
 > > > to revise the spec to reflect what was actually implemented.

Some constraints are not supported in postgresql thats why it is not allowed to use postgresql with rolling upgrades but now the problem is if someone wants to use postgresql and not rolling upgrades then it is not possible (IMO). If that is Ok then this patch having db_check as a separate check makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-07 14:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)

Suggestions for the release note.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-07 14:51:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Abhishek: thank you for pointing out the implications of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433934/, we need to look into that right away. (Just want to clarify that issue is independent of this patch.)'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-07 14:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-08 04:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2

I think this is independent of the postgres issue.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2018-02-08 05:11:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

minor changes in the release note, once it is corrected I think I will put +2A, considering brian's +2 as it is due to no changes in code."}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-02-08 06:41:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2018-02-08 06:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Implementation of db check command

This patch adds a new "glance-manage db check" command
which will check the current state of the users upgrade
repos and relay info back to the user if the user has any
outstanding db upgrades left to run with appropriate exit code.

Co-Authored-By: Bhagyashri Shewale <bhagyashri.shewale@nttdata.com>

Implements: Ie1e2fec2361765ddf23da897abcf0e12e682612e
Change-Id: I1e0b02d615690f65a17b4ccfe4e4a72cc9e15ada

subject: Updated the README.md content
messages:
[{'account_id': 27644, 'date': '2018-02-08 13:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-02-08 13:08:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27644, 'date': '2018-02-08 13:12:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I888f93d756037386f3da5fca4bc2232f1d8ccf7d

commit_message:
Remove tags from upgrade tasks for aide.yml.

After merging [0], the step for each upgrade_task
is now handled in a 'when' condition. This patch
changes all the 'tags:' in upgrade_tasks to their
corresponding 'when:' statement.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510902/

Change-Id: Id740f69db8ea4ba883a90d9f70a705640c3855d4

commit_message:
expand on openstacksdk cycle highlights

Change-Id: I9e9ad347303a0cc0f6103d75cb9485e05450738a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
